_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: CEPT - Propane certified training from National Propane Gas Association

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction and Polices:

COOP Service Inc. is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. 



The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency action plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.



Applicable Sources and Regulated Substances:

COOP Service Inc. is a wholesale distributer of mobile containers (tank trucks) of propane.  The propane is transloaded from railcar to mobile containers utilizing a Westmor Propane mobile chassis transloader.  Propane is the only substance regulated under the RMP at the COOP Service Inc. Baudette MN facility.  The facility is classified as a Program 2 under the regulation.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at COOP Service, Inc. include:

?    Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations.

?    Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner such that unintentional releases are minimized.

?    Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.

?    Correcting non-compliance found during regular audits of the facility.



Release Scenarios

The transload process has the potential to store up to 25 rail cars of propane on a leased rail line (841,250 gallons nominal water capacity), and potential storage of up to 124,000 gallons nominal water capacity of propane in mobile containers at the process location.  

A worst-case release is defined as the loss of the contents of the single larg

est vessel (or piping) containing the regulated substance. For propane and other flammable substances, the released substance is assumed to explode and generate a pressure wave that can injure people or damage structures. The rule requires determining the distance to a 1 psi overpressure (at 1 psi, windows will break). The maximum quantity of the single largest container is held in a railcar (33,650 gallons nominal water capacity), will result in a 0.4 mile distance to end point.  

The alternative release scenario examined Piping Break on the transloader. This alternative scenario considers a break in propane piping (3 inch in diameter) leading to a 10-minute release and explosion. The distance to the 1 psi endpoint is resulted in a release rate of 4612 lb/minute for a total of 46, 122 lb in 10 minutes with a resulting distance to endpoint of 0.3 miles. 

Prevention Program



COOP Service Inc. stores propane, and requires the facility to implement a Level 2 Prevention Program. The Plant has implemented the prevention program requirements and has completed a hazard review. In addition, the Plant has also implemented operating procedures, training, maintenance activities, emergency action plan, and incident investigation procedures. The employees at the Plant are efficient at performing their duties in a manner that prevents incidents and injuries. The COOP Service Inc. facility maintains a training schedule for all employees in the areas of technical expertise, and safety procedures utilizing the CETP Certification training from NPGA (National Propane Gas Association).



The facility follows the operation, maintenance and inspection system as designed, and meets the recommended manufacturer guidance requirements.  CETP training information, Propane SDS, and the transloader operating manual act as training, procedure, and other documentation of the process requirements.



Emergency Response Program

The facility follows a site emergency action plan for emergency r

esponses.  The facility coordinates all emergency response with the local Baudette fire department and local emergency planning and response agencies.  



Five-Year Accident History and Planned Changes to Improve Safety



No incidents resulting in onsite injuries, death or property damage or offsite impacts from a propane release has occurred at the COOP Service Inc. facility within the last five years.



Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program coupled with the environmental, health and safety management systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement. Some of the key components of the safety program are:



?    Hazard Analysis provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.

?    A maintenance schedule is followed to ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

?    Maintain certified training (CETP) as suggested by the National Propane Gas Association.



Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the terminal include:



?    Compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is periodically being evaluated for improvements.

?    An ongoing dialogue with the Baudette Fire Department will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.

?    Investigate any unanticipated release of propane which may occur during transloading or storage, and implement corrective actions to prevent re-occurence.
